metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Git Workflow
Git Workflow Commands Overview
See Also: GitHub Flow is a popular collaborative workflow for teams using GitHub.
content.html: See Also: GitHub Flow is a popular collaborative workflow for teams using GitHub.

content.text: If you work with GitLab or Bitbucket, those platforms have their own workflows too. Learn more about GitHub Flow »
content.html: If you work with GitLab or Bitbucket, those platforms have their own workflows too. Learn more about GitHub Flow »

content.text: Understanding the Git Workflow
Git uses a distributed workflow that allows you to work on your code, stage changes, and commit them to your local repository before sharing with others.
content.html: Git uses a distributed workflow that allows you to work on your code, stage changes, and commit them to your local repository before sharing with others.

content.text: Understanding this workflow is essential for effective version control.
content.html: Understanding this workflow is essential for effective version control.

content.text: The Three Areas of Git

content.code_html: [Working Directory] --git add--> [Staging Area] --git commit--> [Repository]

content.text: Best Practices for Git Workflow
Working Directory
This is where you make changes to your files.
content.html: This is where you make changes to your files.

content.text: Think of it as your workspace or desk.
content.html: Think of it as your workspace or desk.

content.text: Files here can be new, modified, or deleted, but Git won't save these changes until you stage and commit them.
content.html: Files here can be new, modified, or deleted, but Git won't save these changes until you stage and commit them.

content.text: Staging Changes ( git add )
When you are happy with your changes, you "stage" them with git add .
content.html: When you are happy with your changes, you "stage" them with git add.

content.text: This puts your changes in the Staging Area, like putting your finished letter in an envelope.
content.html: This puts your changes in the Staging Area, like putting your finished letter in an envelope.

content.code_html: git add index.html

content.text: To stage all changes (new, modified, and deleted files):
content.html: To stage all changes (new, modified, and deleted files):

content.code_html: git add .

content.text: Committing Changes ( git commit )
Committing saves your staged changes to your local repository.
content.html: Committing saves your staged changes to your local repository.

content.text: It's like mailing your letter—you can't change it after it's sent!
content.html: It's like mailing your letter—you can't change it after it's sent!

content.code_html: git commit -m "Describe your changes"

content.text: You can also use git commit -a -m "message" to stage and commit all modified and deleted files in one step (but not new files).
content.html: You can also use git commit -a -m "message" to stage and commit all modified and deleted files in one step (but not new files).

content.text: Pushing Changes ( git push )
After you commit, your changes are only in your local repository.
content.html: After you commit, your changes are only in your local repository.

content.text: Use git push to send your commits to a remote repository (like GitHub or Bitbucket) so others can see them.
content.html: Use git push to send your commits to a remote repository (like GitHub or Bitbucket) so others can see them.

content.code_html: git push

content.text: Checking Status ( git status )
Use git status to see which files are staged, unstaged, or untracked.
content.html: Use git status to see which files are staged, unstaged, or untracked.

content.text: This helps you keep track of what you still need to add or commit.
content.html: This helps you keep track of what you still need to add or commit.

content.code_html: git status

content.text: Undoing and Amending Changes
Made a mistake? Git lets you fix things before you push!
content.html: Made a mistake? Git lets you fix things before you push!

content.code_html: git restore --staged index.html

content.text: Tips & Troubleshooting
Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
